What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wasn't able to explore the material much. The assignments were designed to answer her own questions about the material rather than think critically.
I learnt about family dynamics in relation to psychological issues

Learned a lot about family dynamics and what can lead to various sorts of psychopathologies, on the family level. If you are considering going into a career in counseling, clinical psych, or social work, this class is an absolute must!
I learned a lot of the fundamentals of family systems and family therapy. I also learned different perspectives within psychology and some more details about diagnoses.
Understanding family dynamics and family systems theory and how these apply to the development of psychopathology.
I learned a huge amount about how influential families can be in a child's development and psychological health.
I learned all about how psychopathology affect the family unit and its functioning, as well as what family therapy approaches are effective and ineffective at treating different mental disorders.
detailed understanding of all the different ways family can impact mental health, overview of topics like attachment formation, different family structures, etc.
I learned a lot about the ways that family dynamics can impact/interact with psychopathology.
I learned how to think about psychiatric illness in the context of the family system, and how to think critically about approaching treatment with attachment and family context in mind.
I learned a lot about how family dynamics affect basically every aspect of our psychological selves and what is needed from a family to be healthy and raise psychologically well children.

I learnt about the ways psychopathology is maintained and transmitted in the family context and the various factors that influence family contexts and the ways psychopathology is maintained. It taught me the significance of the family context for teaching individuals socialization skills among other key developmental processes and how it interacts later in life with other external factors such as immigration. Overall, this course also gave me a great deal of insight into the ways that contexts can shape individuals and how the family influences individuals throughout their life span.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really wanted to enjoy this class, but I could have read a textbook and learned the same information.

very engaging and an open interactive format
I think there could be less or shorter presentations (or make them group presentations) so they take up less lecture time
I can't think of how to improve this class. It's one of my favorite ever classes and Prof Lockhart is one of my favorite professors.

Strength: Course content was engaging and insightful, especially in learning about your own family! Very flexible/accommodating with assignments. Generally moderate course load.

Weakness: More direction on final assignment.
I think the weaknesses mainly were from the virtual format, it felt more like a small lecture than a seminar which made it challenging to contribute a lot.

Strengths: I loved the deep discussions we got to have after the lecture-style/presentation part of the course, where we would consider the effects of different therapy approaches and bring personal experiences to the table 

Weaknesses: none, asides from the fact that I would have liked if student presentations had less of a focus

strengths: covers so many different topics, well organized assignments
weaknesses: none
The class was largely lecturing, despite it being listed as a seminar. I would have loved more time to discuss!

I found the course material really engaging, and I thought that the structure of the course was very well facilitated to student learning. I think that the course could be improved by including more discussion in each class meeting.

The lecture material was very interesting and was a great summary of all the current literature on a specific psychopathology and its relationship with the family (e.g., BPD and the family). The final projects and presentations were also great practice for any psychological researcher that wants to learn how to communicate their ideas and design their own research questions. The only weakness of the course was that there were not many opportunities to improve our research paper, since there were no TFs.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Lockhart lowered the number of weekly assignments required, which helped take some stress of the end of the semester for me.
it was all successful
I think this class was great in the online format. Prof Lockhart did a great hob of keeping the class engaging online.
More discussion following mini lectures
I think the student presentations really helped me to learn from my peers and engage with the course material.
The virtual lectures were very effective but it was difficult to have spontaneous discussions in the break out rooms.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No I wouldn't. There are so many other Psychology seminars that are more engaging.
yes, so interesting and engaging and Professor was amazing
I would recommend to students who are interested in pursuing a career in counseling, social work, or clinical psychology!
I definitely would! It was fantastic.
Yes. It helps you understand your own family dynamics, which is nice. Great for future clinical psychologists.
Definitely! A wonderful class to learn more about yourself and those around you. Dr. Lockhart is so knowledgeable and truly cares about her students.
Yes, I really enjoyed it!

yes!! professor Lockhart is really enthusiastic about what she teaches, and she is truly and genuinely engaged with her students in class. the content is also key for a psychology major, because the course discusses real-life implications of mental illness and trauma on families- super important if clinical psychology is something you are interested in!
I would definitely recommend this course to another student  for anyone considering clinical psychology as a career path I think this is a very informative and applicable course!
Yes!!! Dr. Lockhart is amazing and the material is so important and applicable to every day life. I also was never too stressed about the course and the work was very manageable.

I highly recommend this course to any student, since we do not realize how crucial the family context is in shaping individuals and maintaining psychopathology. This course is perfect for any student interested in psychopathology, and the ways in which environments and contexts are crucial for shaping the disorder and its trajectory.

comments: none
